page.title: 15PLACES OF INTEREST
page.content: These are the two best known landmarks of our area.{Grin Low}is a hill{1440 {feet(455metres)}high. The word {'Low' is Anglo-Saxon for small mound; usually a burial mound. When it was excvated in 1894 a {neolithic burial {mound}was discovered. 3 skeletons and the burnt remains of others and some food jars were found. c1836 a tower was built on Grin Low to give work to local unemployed men. By the 1890s it had collapsed. In{1896}a local farmer{-Solomon Mycock-}built a folly known now as {Solomon's Temple.} It is a round, one storey tower with a castellated top and large rounded top windows. From the top you get a good view of our survey area and of Mam Tor, Kinder Scout and Buxton town. We sheltered there on our field trip.
